title: Robert Joseph Pothier
text:
Robert Joseph Pothier (9 January 1699 – 2 March 1772) was a French <a href="jurist">jurist</a>.
Life.
He was born and passed away at <a href="Orl%C3%A9ans">Orléans</a>. He studied <a href="law">law</a> to qualify for the magistracy, and was appointed Judge in 1720 of the Presidial Court of Orléans, following in the footsteps of his father and grandfather. He held the post for fifty-two years.
Pothier paid particular attention to the correction and co-ordination of the text of the <a href="Pandects">Pandects</a>. His "Pandectae Justinianae in novum ordinem digestae" (Paris and Chartres, 1748-1752) is a classic in the study of <a href="Roman%20law">Roman law</a>. In 1749 he was made professor of law at the <a href="University%20of%20Orleans">University of Orleans</a>.
He wrote many learned monographs on <a href="French%20law">French law</a>, and much of his work was incorporated almost textually in the French "Code Civil". His theories on the law of contract were influential in England as well as in the United States.
Pothier devised a law limiting recovery in the case of improper performance of a contractual obligation to those damages which are foreseeable.
His wrote numerous treatises. His works have been published in collected form on several occasions, the first edited by Giffrein in 1820-1824.
Legacy.
According to Janwillem Oosterhuis, "like <a href="Jean%20Domat">Domat</a>, Pothier's methodology did not consist of constructing an ideal type of Natural law but rather the application of rationalistic methods to existing law, in particular Roman law and customary law."
